hint.text: A state function is a thermodynamic quantity whose value only depends on the present state. The value of a state function is independent of the history of the system.

solution.text:
A state function is a thermodynamic quantity whose value only depends on the present state. The value of a state function is independent of the history of the system.
In the quantities below:
  • Internal Energy (U), Temperature (T), Pressure (P) and Enthalpy (H) are state functions since they don't depend on the path or history of the system.
  • Heat (Q) and Work (W) are not state functions since they change depending on the path or history of the system regardless of whether the final state is equivalent.
